articles.headline: Housing Market Gives Hints of a Thaw
articles.snippet: Various arms of the federal government swung into action this week to boost the economy. Yet for many, the incentives are not enough.
articles.abstract: Various arms of the federal government swung into action this week to boost the economy. Yet for many, the incentives are not enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROMEOVILLE, Ill.  The temperature was in the single digits and the forecast for the real estate market was even chillier, but Fran and Mark Gable went out the other day to see about buying a four-bedroom house.

articles.headline: Hate to Spoil a Weekend, but ....
articles.snippet: I don’t see how you can avoid a certain amount of gloom given the week we’ve just had — and its implications for the future of the U.S. economy.
articles.abstract: I don’t see how you can avoid a certain amount of gloom given the week we’ve just had — and its implications for the future of the U.S. economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in his mid-1980s heyday, when he was America’s most famous investor, managing America’s most famous mutual fund, Peter Lynch used to hate Mondays. Monday, you see, was the day the market was most likely to go down; according to research Mr. Lynch had compiled, from 1955 to 1985, it dropped by a cumulative 1,500 points just on that one day.

articles.headline: As State Primary Nears, Pataki Is Barely Visible
articles.snippet: Once New York’s dominant Republican politician, former Gov. George E. Pataki is virtually absent from the scene.
articles.abstract: Once New York’s dominant Republican politician, former Gov. George E. Pataki is virtually absent from the scene.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Gov. George E. Pataki left office last January, he was the dominant Republican politician in New York. Over three terms, he had shattered fund-raising records and had racked up double-digit victory margins in an overwhelmingly Democratic state, becoming a national political figure in the process. Mr. Pataki ruled Albany for so long that even now some swatches of state bureaucracy are still run by his political appointees.

articles.headline: Building Costs Deal Blow to Local Budgets
articles.snippet: In many parts of the country, state and local governments are struggling to pay for roads, bridges and other projects because of rising construction costs.
articles.abstract: In many parts of the country, state and local governments are struggling to pay for roads, bridges and other projects because of rising construction costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  State and local governments in many parts of the country are struggling to pay for roads, bridges and other building projects because of rising construction costs, adding another burden to budgets already stressed by the troubled housing market.

articles.headline: McCain’s Fiscal Mantra Becomes Less Is More
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain says he can accomplish what other presidents have failed to do: cut spending sharply while also lowering taxes.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain says he can accomplish what other presidents have failed to do: cut spending sharply while also lowering taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Senator John McCain said that, if elected, he would do what other presidents had tried but failed to do: cut government spending sharply enough to reduce the budget deficit while lowering taxes at the same time.

articles.headline: Britain Seeks Its Essence, and Finds Punch Lines
articles.snippet: A government proposal to define the country’s national identity has prompted shrugs, scorn and British humor.
articles.abstract: A government proposal to define the country’s national identity has prompted shrugs, scorn and British humor.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  It was a lofty idea: formulate a British “statement of values” defining what it means to be British, much the way a document like the Declaration of Independence sets out the ideals that help explain what it means to be American.

articles.headline: French Trader Is Remembered as Mr. Average
articles.snippet: Until Jérôme Kerviel was charged in unprecedented fraud, there was nothing superlative about him.
articles.abstract: Until Jérôme Kerviel was charged in unprecedented fraud, there was nothing superlative about him.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Jérôme Kerviel was too middling to be considered a loser. Until he was charged by Société Générale with perpetrating the biggest fraud of its kind in banking history, there was nothing superlative about him.
articles.byline: By Doreen Carvajal and Caroline Brothers

articles.headline: At Elite Prep Schools, College-Size Endowments
articles.snippet: Endowments at some independent schools have become so big that trustees have hired full-time money managers.
articles.abstract: Endowments at some independent schools have become so big that trustees have hired full-time money managers.
articles.lead_paragraph: EXETER, N.H.  When Curtis Thomas, a 14-year-old from a poor family living in St. Rose, La., arrived here two years ago to attend Phillips Exeter Academy, he brought little more than a pair of jeans and two shirts. That would hardly do at a 227-year-old prep school where ties are still required for boys in class.

articles.headline: Belt-Tightening, but No Collapse, Is Forecast in Technology Spending
articles.snippet: The outlook for growth in technology spending is encouraging, according to corporate technology buyers and industry analysts.
articles.abstract: The outlook for growth in technology spending is encouraging, according to corporate technology buyers and industry analysts.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the consumer economy, the Main Street shopper leads the way. In the corporate economy, big technology buyers like Monte Ford will determine the arc of business spending in the coming months.

articles.headline: Société Générale’s Sales May Have Incited Market Plunge
articles.snippet: The bank’s abrupt reversal of positions on Monday contributed to a decline that snowballed into an avalanche of sell orders around the world, some traders said.
articles.abstract: The bank’s abrupt reversal of positions on Monday contributed to a decline that snowballed into an avalanche of sell orders around the world, some traders said.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  As panic swept European markets on Monday, word spread that a big hedge fund was in trouble and dumping stocks.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: Obama Carries South Carolina by Wide Margin
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama’s commanding victory over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton amid record-setting turnout sets the stage for a state-by-state fight.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama’s commanding victory over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton amid record-setting turnout sets the stage for a state-by-state fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Senator Barack Obama won a commanding victory over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the South Carolina Democratic primary on Saturday, drawing a wide majority of black support and one-quarter of white voters in a contest that sets the stage for a multistate fight for the party’s presidential nomination.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: Obama Weathers a Test of Mettle
articles.snippet: With his victory in South Carolina, Senator Barack Obama proved he could endure what the Clintons threw at him and draw votes across racial lines.
articles.abstract: With his victory in South Carolina, Senator Barack Obama proved he could endure what the Clintons threw at him and draw votes across racial lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Senator Barack Obama proved in South Carolina on Saturday that he could not only endure everything the Clinton campaign threw at him in the most confrontational week of the presidential contest so far but also draw votes across racial lines even in a Southern state.

articles.headline: Pakistan Shuns C.I.A. Buildup Sought by U.S.
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s president dismissed proposals to allow the U.S. greater latitude in territories where militants are active.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s president dismissed proposals to allow the U.S. greater latitude in territories where militants are active.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The top two American intelligence officials traveled secretly to Pakistan early this month to press President Pervez Musharraf to allow the Central Intelligence Agency greater latitude to operate in the tribal territories where Al Qaeda, the Taliban and other militant groups are all active, according to several officials who have been briefed on the visit.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Royal Pay at Delphi, Reined in by a Judge
articles.snippet: Managers won’t get $87 million for exiting bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Managers won’t get $87 million for exiting bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORE than two years ago, the Delphi Corporation, an automotive parts giant, filed for bankruptcy protection. Even as it asked workers, creditors and owners to accept big losses, Delphi requested a lush executive pay package that included $87 million in cash bonuses to be paid to top managers upon the company’s exit from bankruptcy. It was a wonderful example of unshared sacrifice that has become deplorably common in corporate America.

articles.headline: What’s $34 Billion on Wall Street?
articles.snippet: For many top Wall Street executives, humiliation and defeat do not necessarily result in professional exile.
articles.abstract: For many top Wall Street executives, humiliation and defeat do not necessarily result in professional exile.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNDER the stewardship of Dow Kim and Thomas G. Maheras, Merrill Lynch and Citigroup built positions in subprime-related securities that led to $34 billion in write-downs last year. The debacle cost chief executives their jobs and brought two of the world’s premier financial institutions to their knees.

articles.headline: In More Cases, Combat Trauma Is Taking the Stand
articles.snippet: Prosecutors, judges and juries are increasingly prodded to assess the role of combat trauma in crimes by veterans.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors, judges and juries are increasingly prodded to assess the role of combat trauma in crimes by veterans.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it came time to sentence James Allen Gregg for his conviction on murder charges, the judge in South Dakota took a moment to reflect on the defendant as an Iraq combat veteran who suffered from severe post-traumatic stress disorder.
articles.byline: By Deborah Sontag and Lizette Alvarez

articles.headline: Saving Sears Doesn’t Look Easy Anymore
articles.snippet: The problem, analysts say, boils down to this: Customers are avoiding Sears stores in droves.
articles.abstract: The problem, analysts say, boils down to this: Customers are avoiding Sears stores in droves.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Gretchen Morgenson, Michael Barbaro and Geraldine Fabrikant and written by Ms. Morgenson.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson, Michael Barbaro and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: Loan Reviewer Aiding Inquiry Into Big Banks
articles.snippet: The company will provide evidence that banks had detailed information about the risks posed by ill-fated subprime mortgages.
articles.abstract: The company will provide evidence that banks had detailed information about the risks posed by ill-fated subprime mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: A company that analyzed the quality of thousands of home loans for investment banks has agreed to provide evidence to New York state prosecutors that the banks had detailed information about the risks posed by ill-fated subprime mortgages.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: With a Whisper, Cuba’s Housing Market Booms
articles.snippet: Nearly all of Havana is owned by the state, but its residents are as obsessed with real estate as New Yorkers.
articles.abstract: Nearly all of Havana is owned by the state, but its residents are as obsessed with real estate as New Yorkers.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA  Virtually every square foot of this capital city is owned by the socialist state, which would seem sure to put a damper on the buying and selling of property.

articles.headline: Direct-to-DVD Releases Shed Their Loser Label
articles.snippet: Once a dumping ground for movies considered virtually unwatchable, the direct-to-DVD pipeline is becoming increasingly important to mainstream film franchises.
articles.abstract: Once a dumping ground for movies considered virtually unwatchable, the direct-to-DVD pipeline is becoming increasingly important to mainstream film franchises.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  If you missed the red-carpet premiere for the latest “American Pie” movie, you are not alone. There wasn’t one. “American Pie Presents: Beta House,” the sixth film in the popular comedy series, was sent straight to DVD.

articles.headline: Kennedy Chooses Obama, Spurning Plea by Clintons
articles.snippet: Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s endorsement pits members of the nation’s most prominent Democratic families against each other.
articles.abstract: Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s endorsement pits members of the nation’s most prominent Democratic families against each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, rejecting entreaties from the Clintons and their supporters, is set to endorse Senator Barack Obama’s presidential bid on Monday as part of an effort to lend Kennedy charisma and connections before the 22-state Feb. 5 showdown for the Democratic nomination.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Yemen’s Deals With Jihadists Unsettle the U.S.
articles.snippet: Yemen has been a valuable recruiting ground and refuge for Islamist militants in the past two decades.
articles.abstract: Yemen has been a valuable recruiting ground and refuge for Islamist militants in the past two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen  When the Yemeni authorities released a convicted terrorist of Al Qaeda named Jamal al-Badawi from prison last October, American officials were furious. Mr. Badawi helped plan the attack on the American destroyer Cole in 2000, in which 17 American sailors were killed.

articles.headline: Fox Mashes Up the Supers
articles.snippet: The network’s coverage of Super Bowl Sunday and Super Duper Tuesday will meld.
articles.abstract: The network’s coverage of Super Bowl Sunday and Super Duper Tuesday will meld.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox is going to get an early jump on Super Sunday. At 9 a.m. E.S.T. next Sunday morning  more than nine hours before the coin is tossed  players and tactics will be scrutinized, coaches will get the once-over, and sideline savants will predict the outcome.

articles.headline: For Gay Democrats, a Primary Where Rights Are Not an Issue, This Time
articles.snippet: For the first time in two decades, the leading Democratic presidential candidates are staking out similar positions on issues that resonate with gay men and lesbians.
articles.abstract: For the first time in two decades, the leading Democratic presidential candidates are staking out similar positions on issues that resonate with gay men and lesbians.
articles.lead_paragraph: The impromptu debate, over light beers and dirty martinis, was at once mundane and remarkable. Provoked by a reporter, four middle-aged men at a Greenwich Village gay bar made fiery pitches for the Democratic presidential front-runners. Two backed Senator Barack Obama, one argued for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, and the fourth made an emotional plea for the cause of John Edwards, the former senator from North Carolina.

articles.headline: A French Style of Capitalism Is Now Stained
articles.snippet: Société Générale, the French bank that earned the respect of it rivals, is now embarrassed by a rogue trader.
articles.abstract: Société Générale, the French bank that earned the respect of it rivals, is now embarrassed by a rogue trader.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  In a country where the hurly-burly of market capitalism has long been viewed with suspicion, Société Générale was a rare Gallic success story  the Chanel or Château Margaux of French banking.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Is It a Recession? Marketers Seem to Think So
articles.snippet: Let the economists and politicians debate whether the American economy is in a recession. Madison Avenue is already battening down the hatches.
articles.abstract: Let the economists and politicians debate whether the American economy is in a recession. Madison Avenue is already battening down the hatches.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let the economists and politicians debate whether the American economy is in a recession. Madison Avenue is already battening down the hatches.

articles.headline: Paulson’s Deal-Making Revives Treasury’s Relevance
articles.snippet: After trying in vain for two years, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. is finally having some success building bipartisan bridges.
articles.abstract: After trying in vain for two years, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. is finally having some success building bipartisan bridges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In his first two years as Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr. spent much of his time learning what his can-do pragmatism could not do.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Races Entering Complex Phase Over Delegates
articles.snippet: The candidates are moving beyond state-by-state competition and into a potentially protracted scramble for delegates.
articles.abstract: The candidates are moving beyond state-by-state competition and into a potentially protracted scramble for delegates.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI  The presidential campaign is entering a new phase as Democratic and Republican candidates move beyond state-by-state competition and into a potentially protracted scramble for delegates Congressional district by Congressional district.

articles.headline: Sallie Mae Settles Suit Over Buyout That Fizzled
articles.snippet: The embattled student lending giant, reached a settlement over its scuttled $25 billion buyout, ending months of legal fighting.
articles.abstract: The embattled student lending giant, reached a settlement over its scuttled $25 billion buyout, ending months of legal fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sallie Mae, the embattled student lending giant, reached a settlement on Sunday over its scuttled $25 billion buyout, ending months of legal fighting that had cast a cloud over the company, according to people briefed on the agreement.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Rapid Changes Since 2001 Cloud Outlook for Viewers
articles.snippet: Amid widespread worries about the economy, media companies must try to divine what a possible recession means for consumers and advertisers.
articles.abstract: Amid widespread worries about the economy, media companies must try to divine what a possible recession means for consumers and advertisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few months ago, media companies were facing declining readership, flat advertising and the prospect of a damaging writers’ strike.
